title.value: Patient experience or patient satisfaction? A systematic review of child- and family-reported experience measures in pediatric surgery
title.justification: The title is explicitly mentioned at the beginning of the document.
title.quote: Patient experience or patient satisfaction? A systematic review of child- and family-reported experience measures in pediatric surgery

extractions.description: This paper is a systematic review assessing Patient-Reported Experience Measures (PREMs) in pediatric surgery. It focuses on identifying the instruments used, their characteristics, and areas for improvement in comparing them to satisfaction surveys. The findings highlight the limited usage of PREMs and the need for their development and implementation in pediatric surgical care.

type.justification: The paper conducts a systematic review, which involves collecting and analyzing data from various studies to draw empirical conclusions about the use of PREMs.
type.quote: This study systematically reviewed the use of PREMs in pediatric general surgery.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on patient experience measures within the healthcare system, specifically in pediatric surgery.
name.quote: PROMs and PREMs are increasingly recognized as important health care quality indicators.

name.justification: The paper specifically reviews PREMs in the context of pediatric surgical care.
name.quote: The use of PREMs in pediatric surgery is limited, prompting this systematic review to assess their characteristics and identify areas for improvement.

name.justification: A central theme of the paper is the measurement and evaluation of patient experiences in healthcare settings.
name.quote: Patient-reported experience measures (PREMs) are critical for collecting information on patient care.
